_exec_summary.SummaryText:
United Suppliers Inc-Charles City is committed to preventing and/or mitigating episodic chemical releases that could lead to a catastrophe in the workplace and possibly the surrounding community.

United Suppliers-Charles City, IA Risk Management Plan is a Predictive Filing.  The facility's primary activity at this location is the blending and storing of wholesale liquid fertilizer.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck or railcarand is blended with phosphoric acid into 10-34-0 liquid fertilizer.  This blending operation is performed by a portable T-Reactor and this reaction takes place twice a year, normally during one week in th spring and one week in the fall.  Anhydrous ammonia is present at the facility only during the blending opeations.

United Suppliers Inc- Charles City, IA recognizs the portable T-reactor as part of the covered process consistent with OSHA regulations 29 CFR Part 1910, Process Safety Management.  The reactor operations when contracted by others is covered by a separate Process Safety Management Plan (owned by the contract organization).  The operations, management of change, pre-statup review, and maintenance procedures for the portable reactor resides with the owner and operator of the portable reactor.  The Emergency Response procedures for the Charles City site and contracted organization are integrated into one response, prior to the reacting operations.

United Suppliers-Charles City, IA  has taken the necessary steps to comply with accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The following biefly describes the prevention program elements in place at this stationary source.

Process Safety information:  The facility maintains information describing the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.

Process Hazard Analysis:  Studies are conducted to ensure the hazards associated with process operations are identified, understood, and controlled.

Operatin

g procedures:  Written operating procedures are maintianed for covered process operations.  These procedures address the following activities:  initial start up, normal, temporary, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown and startup following a turnaround.

Training:  A program is in place to ensure employees and contractors are knowledgeable and trained in procedues associated with the covered process.

Mechanical Integrity:  Covered process equipment is maintained consistent with generald accepted engineering practices.  Covered process equipment is routinely inspected and tested.  Covered process equipment viability assessments includes: storage vessels, piping system, relief nd vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance activities are conducted by qualified personnel.  Deficiencies are corrected in a timely manner.

Management of Change:  Written procedures are in place to manage changes in the process chemicals technology, equipment, and/or procedures.  Affected personnel are informed and trained to deal with authorized system changes.

Pre-Start Up review:  Technical and operational reviews will be conducted on new process and/or modification to existing covered process and/or procedures. Reviews confirm the construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures, are suitable.  Reviews are completed prior to placing the equipment in operation.

Compliance Audits:  Internal audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions specified under the RMP rules are being implemented.  At a minimum, these audits are conducted every three (3) years.  Any determined corrective actions are completed in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation:  Investigations are conducted to determine the root cause of the covered process incidents.  In addition to determination and corrective action, investigations are directed towards preventing reoccurence.  Investigations become process safety information and are retained for

five (5) years.

Employee Participation:  United Suppliers - Charles City, IA actively contribute to the following:  process hazard assesments, operating procedures development, maintenance procedures development, training development and implementation, pre-statup review, incident investigations, and compliance audits.  Additionally, employees have access to all information pertaining to the facility's RMP.

Contractors:   Periodically, United Suppliers, Charles City, IA  hires contractors to conduct specialized operational, maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to work and reviewed annually, the contractors are trained and audited on the covered process, relevant process safety information and emergeny response actions.

Five (5) year Accident History:  There has been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five (5) years that hae resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage.  Nor to our knowledge, has there been any releases that resulted in off-site deaths, inuries, evacuations, property damage and/or environmental damage.

Emergency Action Plan:  United Suppliers Inc., Charles City, IA has a written Emergency Action Plan.  This plan includes notification of Floyd County LEPC.  Local authorities have been provided  with emergency planning and community right-to-know information.

Planned changes and improve safety:  United Suppliers Inc. Charles City, IA views improvement as a continual process.  Periodic evaluations (both internal and external) are performed to assess he facility status.  At this time, and asside from sustaining maintenance activities, there are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding anhydrous ammonia.
